Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: POGIL Math - Guided Inquiry Materials for Gatekeeper Courses in Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative project is applying the approach of Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL), which has been successful in chemistry, to undergraduate pre-calculus and first semester calculus courses. The team's work is guided by three main goals: i) to create new POGIL learning materials for pre-calculus and calculus where reform will have a large and visible impact; ii) to develop faculty expertise within the mathematics community to implement these new materials by presenting math-specific POGIL workshops at national mathematics meetings and POGIL summer workshops; and iii) to conduct in depth research on undergraduate mathematics education by implementing a case study design to examine learning in POGIL MATH classroom contexts. Several factors contribute to the strong intellectual merit of this project. First, the PI team brings together combined expertise in (1) authoring high quality POGIL chemistry activities; (2) curricular innovations in mathematics; (3) mathematics education research; and (4) evaluation. Second, the POGIL Project's National Office is lending support in training and dissemination. Moreover, because POGIL is a nationally tested and proven pedagogical strategy based on research on how students learn, classroom materials generated as part of the proposed project are expected to generate results in mathematics similar to those in chemistry: a) improved student learning; b) decreased attrition (especially among underrepresented minority students); c) improved attitudes toward mathematics; and d) increased faculty adoptions. The project is exercising its broader impact in several ways. First, the case study design of the project's research component is informing the mathematics community about how POGIL activities can challenge student misconceptions in calculus as identified in the mathematics education literature, as well as how classroom context affects implementation of POGIL activities. Second, the materials developed in this project are being classroom tested in diverse settings, both by the authors and by beta-testers, hence increasing the potential transportability of these POGIL mathematics activities to any faculty member's classroom. In addition, several of the institutions directly involved in the development of the POGIL calculus materials have large percentages of underrepresented students taking calculus, and thus any curricular change is in the position to have a significant impact on retention of minority students and women. Finally, the variety of institutions both in the collaborative and among the pilot test sites are expanding the network of POGIL experts, spanning a variety of post-secondary institutions, regions throughout the U.S., and disciplines, thus having a potentially transformative effect on mathematics instruction in the undergraduate STEM education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) is a nationally tested and proven pedagogical strategy based on research on how students learn. It initiated in chemistry departments in the 1990s, and has since expanded to many other areas of science.  The major goals of the “Collaborative Research: POGIL Math - Guided Inquiry Materials for Gatekeeper Courses in Mathematics” project were to create guided inquiry classroom activities using the POGIL approach in undergraduate pre-calculus and first semester calculus courses; develop faculty expertise and foster faculty buy-in within the mathematics community to implement these new materials by presenting math-specific POGIL introductory and advanced writing workshops at local, regional, and national mathematics meetings and at a diverse range of universities across the United States; conduct research on undergraduate mathematics education by implementing a case study design to examine learning in POGIL mathematics classroom contexts.

 

By the end of the grant period, the project team members had written, classroom tested, beta-tested (in non-author classrooms), edited, and published a set of 32 activities for Calculus I, and written, classroom tested, beta-tested, and edited 27 activities that can be used for college algebra or for pre-calculus. There was also one high school teacher who participated in POGIL training and implemented POGIL materials in a high school calculus class. The principal investigators also developed and ran numerous workshops and mini-courses, both introductory and advanced, at regional and national meetings and at universities across the United States.  Team members also collected a rich set of video observations from author and non-author classrooms, as well as student interview data, quiz data, retention data, pre/post data on students’ mathematical dispositions and attitudes toward mathematics. Analysis of that data has shown improved student learning, decreased attrition (especially among underrepresented minority students), and improved attitudes toward mathematics. The project generated an expanded network of POGIL experts, spanning a variety of post-secondary institutions and regions throughout the U.S. The mathematics education research has revealed that the activities and the POGIL method, when it is implemented well, provide opportunities for students to engage with fellow students and the classroom teacher to develop significant ideas of calculus as well as address common misconceptions beginning students often have about calculus concepts. This research also revealed that POGIL teachers need adequate training in POGIL methods in order to implement the activities well and that some teachers that had only minimal training missed opportunities for engaging students in POGIL inquiry. The case study of the high school calculus classroom revealed that POGIL teaching methods and calculus activities have great potential to benefit student learning in high school mathematics classrooms. Based on our preliminary findings here, future research should investigate the impact that POGIL pre-calculus and calculus could have on high school mathematics classrooms. Finally, some of the students in the case studies reported enjoying learning calculus in POGIL classrooms because they felt more intellectual ownership over their learning than in traditional lecture classrooms. Given that lecture is still the dominant mode of instruction in STEM college classrooms, this initial work provides some evidence that may be convincing to faculty and college administrators to invest in POGIL training and adopting POGIL materials for calculus classes.
